subject: probability
title: Negative Binomial Distribution
contentHtml:
The Negative Binomial Distribution (NBD) models the number of failures until a specified number of successes is reached.

This distribution is related to the Geometric Distribution and can be used to model overdispersion in count data.
latex: \[X \sim NB(r, p) \quad \text{where } X = k\] (number of failures until $k$ successes)",
name: Negative Binomial Distribution" },
problemHtml: Suppose we want to model the number of attempts until a customer purchases an item. We know that on average, it takes 3 attempts for a customer to buy something.

steps.description: Determine the number of successes (purchases) and failures (attempts without purchase)
steps.explanation: We can use the NBD to model this process.

intuition: The NBD is useful when modeling overdispersion in count data, where the variance exceeds the mean.

The Negative Binomial Distribution (NBD) is a discrete probability distribution that models the number of failures until a specified number of successes are achieved.

This distribution is closely related to the Geometric Distribution and can be used to model overdispersion in data.
